title: Telegraphist 1920: Beats of War
tagline: Made narrative-driven rhythm game for HackYeah 2022 during 24 hours in 6-person team. Won 2nd place in Game Development #1 - Polish Great Battles category.
shortDescription: Made narrative-driven rhythm game for HackYeah 2022 during 24 hours in 6-person team. Won 2nd place in Game Development #1 - Polish Great Battles category and received recognition from Centrum Rozwoju Przemysłów Kreatywnych (CRPK).

details.content: Project Leader | Gameplay Programmer | Audio Designer | Game Designer | UI Designer

sections.text:
In October 2022, I was taking part in HackYeah 2022 hackathon. We've received second place by vote of jury.

During 24 hours I was responsible for: 
• designing and implementing UI with animations using DOTween, 
 • programming visual-audio to BPM response,
 • creating audio using interwar period samples and mixing it dynamically in Unity, 
 • deploying an iteration system (creating a feature, testing and improving based on the feedback from other people around us).

Link to the gamejam version: https://thematiaz0.itch.io/1920-telegraphist

In April 2023, we were given the opportunity to get a fund from CRPK to work on a prototype of Telegraphist 1920: Beats of War.

During this, I have programmed Level Editor to create base for us and future modders, deliver milestones with builds showcasing our progress and handled optimization for final demo in Unity.

In October 2024, the four of us had opportunity to show up at Poznań Game Arena 2024 and say hi to our fans, but also present people to new audience. The feedback from everyone was very valuable and the place seemed very inspirational for me (especially afterparty :P)

In November 2024, we received another grant, this time for marketing expansion. During this time, I managed to create a port of Telegraphist 1920 for Steam Deck handheld, organized a focus test to make sure that we'll get Steam Deck Verified status (fingers crossed!) and executed all marketing ideas (aside from our TikTok socials).

Nowadays, I'm still working on the game in my free time and we intend to release it on Steam in 2025.

My role right now is various - from leading our programming team to contacting video game festivals and events around the world.
In addition to this, I work on adding more juicyness to the game with VFX, shaders and UI. Isn't it what rhythm games are about?

Check out my article on Medium on that topic: https://medium.com/@mateusz.kusionowicz/how-to-create-a-new-evolution-of-guitar-hero-a-tale-of-telegraphist-1920-game-design-process-6f68736742d0

title: Keep it Cool, Man
tagline: Created an arcade fast-paced typing game with friend and released on Steam for free. This project is perfect definition of jam session.
shortDescription:
Made an arcade fast-paced typing game with friend (+ additional musician) and released it on Steam for free. 

I was responsible for:
 • designing and implementing all of the user interface (including animations created through C# using DOTween).
 • implementing third-party APIs, 
 • created and designed game content (like bomb letters, shotgun letters, etc.).
 • coding Unity editor tools to speed up development process.
 • handling marketing and PR inquires with players, influencers and journalists.

details.content: Gameplay Programmer | Tool Programmer | Animation Programmer (DOTween) | UI/UX Designer

sections.text: I decided to make couple devlogs before game release. They describe our inspirations, contain speedarts of making user interface and explain the philosophy behind Keep it Cool, Man:

At the beginning, I started with feeling for the game which UI would evoke. I chose fear and fun, though it wasn't 100% fear, more like a surprise. Those two fit perfectly in the sarcasm/irony zone for the story and typing game with apocalyptic asteroid letters for the gameplay:

I thought about the style and first things that came to my mind was funk and sci-fi and the name - Keep it Cool, Man (it's long I know, but still it's catchy and tells the player vibe of the game). It came to my mind while thinking about the health system and it being the temperature of the planet seemed like an interesting concept to me and also I like avoiding the same old boring health bar without story explanation:

As soon as possible I created a color palette to create a consistent and memorable experience. I chose the yellow colour as the main one, because it catches the attention and signals an upcoming warning - fitting the feeling of fear:

With level complete screen I wanted to engage players into playing one more level. For that it required the UI to be immersive and simple and every  animation to be seamless (here it shows the transition to the Main Menu, but clicking Next the player would in the same way transition to the next level):

For dialogues I implemented various effects from shaking the screen or avatar (like here it's cellphone) to flexible delay. The background displays the planet that this dialogue is happening on (though I think it could be still improved):
This animated background by the way I programmed using DOTween. I also used Unity Animation Curve to fake vinyl player tonearm movement.

Level collection consists of vinyl discs for each chapter and circles placed onto the disc as levels. The levels also has green or red circles around them indicating if they are locked or unlocked to the player (in this case though, they are all unlocked):

I was also at the Poznań Game Arena 2021 (one of the biggest video game trade show in Poland) where with my friend we showcased Keep it Cool, Man to thousands of people! It was great having all of these feedback from various people and how they play the game!

title: This Game Is Broken
tagline: Built an endless runner platformer game under 72 hours with a four-person team on my first stationary KrakJam 2020. Updated game afterwards and ported to Android.
shortDescription:
Built a game in 72 hours with a four-person team on my first stationary KrakJam 2020.

 I was responsible for: 
• programming glitch effects (screen rotate, audio mix underpitch, camera rotation in 3D space), 
• implementing postprocessing effects,
• implementing using Game Jolt API scoreboard system and login system.

details.content: Gameplay Programmer | Game Designer | Scrum Master

sections.text:
Our work began after reveal of the theme, which in 2020 was repair.

We immediately started thinking about something unconventional, which is... fixing the game you are currently playing.

 Initially, we thought about a platformer shooter, but in the end we decided on an endless runner with the ability to go backwards (the only thing that pushes you forward is a wave of bugged letters like this overflow bug/kill screen in Pac-Man, which our graphic designer was inspired by):
